You can reproduce it on the sample from https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=147228#c5

bug.short_desc: Add help anchors for contributing JET Tag Library and XPath function documentation

long_desc.thetext:
Contributors of help for supplemental JET Tags and/or XPath functions should be able to install their help within the appropriate JET reference sections.
Add help anchors to the JET Help table of contents so that help contributors can do this.
JET Tag Referenc anchor: tagReference XPath function anchor: xpathFunctions
To use the anchors, contributors would typically have the following content for their help table of contents:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?NLS TYPE="org.eclipse.help.toc"?>
<toc link_to="../org.eclipse.jet.doc/toc.xml#tagReference"> ... contributed toc ... </toc>
or
<toc link_to="../org.eclipse.jet.doc/toc.xml#xpathFunctions"> ... contributed toc ... </toc>
Changes committed to CVS.
Resolved in build 0.7.1 M200608311049

bug.short_desc: Window Themes and Multiple Displays: Shell in second Display is not drawn

long_desc.thetext:
Precondition: - Windows XP GUI is set to Windows XP Style (Luna) - No java.exe.manifest File in the used jre - Multiple Displays (Two instances of org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display)
The content of a Shell opened in the second Display is not drawn. Example Programm and ScreenShoot attached.
It does not matter if the Displays/Shells exist at the same time or if the first Display is disposed before the second is created.
As soon as the Windows GUI is switched to "Windows Classic" or the java.exe.manifest/javaw.exe.manifest is created, it works. (http://www.eclipse.org/swt/javaw.exe.manifest)
The problem was reproducible on another machine without XP SP2. The Problem was reproducible with the following java-versions: 1.4.2_04, 1.5.0_05, 1.5.0_08. The Problem does not exist with SWT 3.1 (If there is no manifest in 3.1 it uses "Windows Classic")

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] Treeview expand/collapse ignores somewhat quick + and - clicks (doubleclicks)

long_desc.thetext:
- eclipse-SDK-3.2-win32.zip - Windows XP - Sun JDK 1.5.0 Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0-b64) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0-b64, mixed mode)
Clicking on + then - in a tree view ignores successive clicks if they are less than about half a second apart.
This is not a problem in native Windows (Windows explorer, for example).
Fixing this makes applications seem more responsive and improves the user experience. One example scenario would be missing with the mouse and expanding the wrong tree, then collapsing it immediately to expand the right one.
To reproduce: - Start Eclipse 3.2 - Create a Java project, or go to Window->Show View->Other... - Rapidly click on the +/- to expand and collapse a tree. Notice how rapid successive clicks are ignored.

SWT, what are we doing wrong?
Snippet15 seems to behave like the Windows Explorer: Double clicking on a tree item expands it, but double clicking on the + expands on the first click and collapses on the second click, even if the item moved as a result of the expand so that the second click does not actually happen on the item.

You are hooking SWT.DoubleSelection which means that you are providing the actaion when a user double clicks on an item. This disables the expand/collapse behavior of a tree item (otherwise, the expand/collapse would happen, then your double selection action would run and that would be confusing).
Am I missing something?
Are you overriding the operating system default and expand/collapsing the node yourself? If so, you are probably seeing XP animation that is slowing down the operation. Try turning it off to see.
Is the behavior that you want for double clicking to expand and then collapse the tree right away? Seems useless, but correct.

It would make applications written using SWT feel more responsive.
From comment#0: One example scenario would be missing with the mouse and expanding the wrong tree, then collapsing it immediately to expand the right one.

> Is the behavior that you want for double clicking to expand and then collapse > the tree right away? Seems useless, but correct.
Exactly. Actually, I need less time than the default doubleclick delay to realize that I expanded the wrong node. BTW: Under GTK, this already works as expected.
Thanks, works perfect in I20070123-1715.

bug.short_desc: Cannot Save As Image File in jpeg or png or svg when using setAlpha()

long_desc.thetext: To understand the mapping how to set the alpha value in the Graphics2D class you can take a look at the reverse mapping which is done in the Graphics2DtoGraphicsAdapter class. It looks like you will need to create an AlphaComposite class and set it's alpha value, then set it as the composite for the Graphics2D class.

This should likely be upgraded since it will also affect copy/paste to external application if the diagram rendering uses that api (setAlpha).
i.e. - Same steps as above, except instead of exporting to PNG / JPEG, copy the note using <Ctrl-C> and then try to paste into Word.

Purpose: Bugzilla#155818 Cannot Save As Image File in jpeg or png or svg when using setAlpha() - Added support for setting the alpha to the GraphicsToGraphics2DAdaptor class which is used when saving an image file as JPEG, PNG, or SVG and also in copy/paste.
Code Reviewed by: Steve
How tested: Manual Tests: - Tried saving an activity diagram with partitions covering other shapes to all the possible image types. - Copy/pasted the entire diagram into word.
JUnit Tests: org.eclipse.gmf.tests.runtime.diagram.ui -- all passed
Impact on QE: n/a
Impact on Doc: n/a
Impact on build: n/a
Delivered to Stream(s): dev.eclipse.org:/home/technology (R1_0_maintenance)

bug.short_desc: Run As SWT application has an Unsatisfied Link Error

long_desc.thetext:
Version 3.2.1 M20060831-0800 Linux Motif
when I run an application as SWT Application I get the Unsatisfied Link Error as if I had run it as a regular java application

Tod, 'Run as SWT Application' is not SWT, it's. Since I don't have access to a Motif box right now, I can't look into it further to see whether the problem is that we build the library wrong or that 'Run as SWT Application' no longer works. Please load SWT from HEAD (http://www.eclipse.org/swt/cvs.php) and don't use 'Run as SWT Application'. If it is still broken, then SWT is broken.
Is Motif currently broken?

Tod, is the unsatisfied link error that the swt library is not being found, or that the swt library is failing to load because the shipped OpenMotif library is not being found?
If LD_LIBRARY_PATH is not set to point at a directory that contains the shipped OpenMotif library, such as the eclipse root directory, then the unsatisfied link error is not unexpected.
Is there a way you could check this an disable the menu option if it is not there? It is unlikely a user would be able to figure this out on thier own.
We don't own the 'Run as SWT Application' menu item.

Closing report because:
- SWT now finds its libraries on its own at runtime (3.3M4) - Run As SWT Application item has been removed above us (3.3M4) - Eclipse is no longer built on linux-motif (3.3M3)

bug.short_desc: 'Extract Constant' refactoring should force Capitalization

long_desc.thetext:
I would like there to be a checkbox on the 'Extract Constant' refactoring that (when active) would force the typed in text to UPPER case. Often when you start typing the constant name, you are in lower case and you have to go back an retype it. Since it is a java standard that constants are capitalized anyway, why not make it a feature?
Thanks, Ray Case
Hmm, I agree that constants should be named in upper case, but I'm not so convinced that an additional checkbox is a good idea. Sorry, no plans for this.

Thanks for your time, Martin!
However lame I may be, having to switch to caps to type the constant is ALWAYS aggravating when I assume that it should just be CAPs.
Maybe someday!
Thanks again! Ray

Moving to JDT/UI

Followed the steps and I get test Case is detected as shown on the screenshot.

It is very possible, now that you mentioned it, I noticed in the Eclipse 3.2 SDK distribution that there are 2 junits: eclipse\plugins\org.junit_3.8.1 and eclipse\plugins\org.junit4_4.1.0. And it comes like that from the www.eclipse.org website. Could you please look into this?

Yes, that detected it. But why the 4.X doesn't do it?
We still have to support that. Suites in JUnit 4 look different.
Will this feature be added to Eclipse 3.3?
No, this is not in 3.3. Also no plans for 3.4. Help is wanted.

If there is no transformation id, then the created run configuration should be opened, allowing the user to specify the configuration.
Changes committed to CVS.
Resolved in build 0.7.1 M200608311049

bug.short_desc: importing a large workspace PI file causes these jst objects to stay in memory

long_desc.thetext:
In a product based on WTP with a lot of plugins, I imported a workspace with lot of projects, the import took a lot of time, afterwards, I deleted all the projects in the workspace, memory went down
However I saw a few jst objects in memory, in yourkit.
org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.componentcore.J2EEModuleVirtualComponent J2EEComponentClasspathContainer & so
the source of the leak looked like this
org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.componentcore.J2EEModuleVirtualComponent (#0143f7ef) _comp of org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.refactor.operations.ProjectRefactorMetadata$RefererCachingVirtualComponent (#01fed873) virtualComp of org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.refactor.operations.ProjectRefactorMetadata (#01416bcf) value of java.util.HashMap$Entry (#016a6aa3) [35] of java.util.HashMap$Entry[128] (#00702006) table of java.util.HashMap (#0026c313) deletedProjectMetadata of org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.refactor.listeners.ProjectRefactoringListener (#014b3342) listener of org.eclipse.core.internal.events.ResourceChangeListenerList$ListenerEntry (#012ed8d3) [17] of org.eclipse.core.internal.events.ResourceChangeListenerList$ListenerEntry[33] (#00d9d80f) listeners of org.eclipse.core.internal.events.ResourceChangeListenerList (#01c920d6) listeners of org.eclipse.core.internal.events.NotificationManager (#00b7b3f9) notificationManager of org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace (#014962a0) workspace of org.eclipse.core.resources.ResourcesPlugin (#01d6d992)
Created an attachment (id=49178) leak source
the leak source got bad formatting. so attached an image of it.

hi Raj,
the culprit HashMap (ProjectRefactoringListener.deletedProjectMetadata), is populated on PRE_DELETE IResourceChangeEvents and is cleared when the corresponding POST_CHANGE event is received (indicating that either the project has been deleted or renamed).
the logic that is handling the POST_CHANGE events could be missing certain events and leaving stale entries in the map or, in this specific case, the POST_CHANGE event was not generated/received due to another error.
some questions:
-what is the exact WTP build you are testing with? -any relevant errors in the .log file for this case? -can you consistently reproduce the leak? -have you tried generating a WTP-only test case for this?

this was based on the 0824/0825 not sure which one WTP build
all i did was import then select all projects and delete.
not really sure if does or does not happen in WTP only (i thought resource change listeners are in eclipse level, i can try other scenarios)

This resource change listener is WTP-specific.
If you could check the .log file for errors, that would be great.
Does "0824/0825" refer to dates of WTP 1.5.1 M-builds?

If you can get a repro case that works on a WTP-only build, that would be very helpful.
In the meantime, if you could attach the workspace that generated the problem, that would be great (if custom plugins are required to import, a WTP-only repro case will be needed).

note: I've tried the case you describe with the current WTP 1.5.1 build:
-create a workspace and create a bunch of J2EE projects -create a new workspace and import all of the projects from the first workspace -select all projects and delete (can opt to delete all contents or not) -verify that all POST_CHANGE events are received and the deletedProjectMetadata HashMap is cleared

Note: this is likely a duplicate of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=156346 (I'm going to attach a patch soon for that which you can use to test out this scenario)
Q: do you know if there is logic that is added project-level markers in this case?

hi Raj: I'm going to go ahead and resolve this as a duplicate of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=156346; I just committed the fix to CVS for that and there is a patched version of the org.eclipse.jst.j2ee jar attached to the bugzilla.
Please give that a try and reopen if you are still seeing the problem.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 156346 ***
This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.

bug.short_desc: [build path] Adding link dialog accepts invalid selections

long_desc.thetext:
3.2.1 RC3
1. select a Java project 2. Build Path > Link Source... 3. click Browse... 4. select e.g. "My Computer" or "My Network Places" ==> OK remains enabled 5. click OK ==> dialog closes and nothing is inserted ==> focus is not in the field

The dialog showing "My Computer" or "My Network Places" is the native folder dialog. We have no control over that. Important is only that 'Link Source' has the 'Finish Button' disabled after you choose one of these entries. Changing the focus to the field is not common, see new type wizards.

>Changing the focus to the field is not common, see new type wizards. Yes, you are right: the focus is correctly on the button.
>The dialog showing "My Computer" or "My Network Places" is the native folder >dialog. We have no control over that. Agreed, the DirectoryDialog does not make a difference between error and cancel.

bug.short_desc: [build path] Linking source to project should always be available

long_desc.thetext:
3.2.1 RC3
The option to link source to the project is only possible when a project is selected. This should always be available.
Applies to the build path properties dialog and the Build Path menu entries in the Package Explorer.
We don't want to encourrage linking on anything elso that for source folders under the project.
>We don't want to encourrage linking on anything elso that for source folders >under the project. Can you say that in English, so that I can understand? ;-)
I meant that in the package explorer that doesn't make sense. But it makes sense in the 'New project wiards' (second page)
to benno
Created an attachment (id=67238) fix
Also always enabled 'Add source folder' in the DialogPackageExplorer
patch is good
verified in I20070527-0010

bug.short_desc: [build path] New Java project wizard: creating project from source does not complain about non-existing source

long_desc.thetext:
3.2.1 RC3
1. start to create a new Java project 2. select "Create project from existing source" 3. enter an invalid path, e.g. "C:\brokenPath" ==> the wizard does not detect that there is no source even though the entry field title says "existing source" 4. press Finish ==> the wizard creates the project at C:\brokenPath

The term 'Existing source' isn't really correct. It should say 'external location' and you can choose existing or new locations. This is how we had it, but Erich wanted to use the term 'existing source' tomhelp novice users as this is most often the reason why you would choose an extrenal location. No changes planed on that.

>The term 'Existing source' isn't really correct So either you should rename it again or complain or at least explain.
Up to you to reconsider whether to reopen.

I find that very confusing too. I think the problem is, that the location of the new project is intermixed with the question of what the new projects content will be. What about:
---- Location ----------- (.) Workspace ( ) External location Directory: [..................] [Browse] ---- Project Content ----- ( ) Use project folder for source and output (.) Create separate source and ouput folder ( ) Use existing source Directory: [..................] [Browse] ---- JRE ----------------- ...AsIs...
If 'Use existing source' is selected then the source is copied to the location of the new project (if the location is different of course).

The two location boxes will cause trouble. It might force the user to synchronize the two. Dani suggestions was: ---- Location ----------- (.) New project in workspace ( ) New project at external location ( ) Project from existing source Directory: [..................] [Browse] [x] Create in workspace and copy content

OR:
(.) New project in workspace ( ) New project at external location ( ) Project from existing source [x] Create in workspace and copy content
Directory: [..................] [Browse]

(In reply to comment #4) > The two location boxes will cause trouble. It might force the user to > synchronize the two.
I don't see that: If the user selects an external location then either a) The location does exist b) Does not exist
If a then 'Project Content' is disabled and message states that: 'The location exists. Wizard will try to detect source folders, ....' -> No need to synchronize.
If b then the user has now the chance to select existing source, since the location does not exist this existing source must be in a different location-> No need to synchronize.
Do I miss something?

(In reply to comment #5) > OR: > > (.) New project in workspace > ( ) New project at external location > ( ) Project from existing source > [x] Create in workspace and copy content > > Directory: [..................] [Browse]
Mmm, how do you create a project at an external location from source wich is taken from another location? What I don't like about the above is that it does not clearly make a distinction between the location of the new project and the content of the new project. I truly think that this makes the wizard so confusing.
I'd rather leave things as they are. We haven't had any complains lately and we tried hard last time.
*** Bug 199147 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Can we get this out of the RESOLVED/LATER state?

(In reply to comment #10) > Can we get this out of the RESOLVED/LATER state? >
That would make no difference...
The new Plugin Projects layout is: -------------------------------------------- Project name: [foo.bar.project ] [ ] Use default location Location: [ ] [Browse] --------------------------------------------
Using this layout would just lead to a situation where it is not obvious anymore for new users, that they can create a new project from existing source. And it has been decided, that this is a more important feature then the feature that it is possible to create a new project outside the workspace. This is reasonable.

bug.short_desc: Diagram event broker uses finalize to do clean up

long_desc.thetext: Diagram event borker uses finalize to do cleanup which includes calling stop listenning on all other diagram event broker instances.
Fixed

bug.short_desc: [build path] New Java project wizard: creating project from source shows strange message

long_desc.thetext:
3.2.1 RC3
1. start to create a new Java project 2. select "Create project from existing source" 3. enter an valid path, e.g. "C:\brokenPath" ==> the wizard does disables the settings (good) and shows a strange message below them: "The specified external location already exists. ...."
Of course it does exists: I was asked to enter an existing location, wasn't I.
I think the blurb is to explain why the settings are disabled. It would be better to show this on top of the settings, e.g. "The settings below are disabled because they are inferred from the given project".
I think we should remove the 'already' in this sentence: 'The specified location is an existing directory. ...'
new project wizard polish
Created an attachment (id=63715) fix

Tested in I20070503-1400: the shown string is still wrong (the suggestion from comment 1 would be closer to what I expect): it now shows: "The wizard will automatically configure the JRE and the project layout based on the specified existing source."
BUT: there is really no source in there: it is completely empty and hence "specified existing source" is just wrong.
I recommend to: 1. rename the radio item to "existing location" which reflects the facts and would be better alligned to the wizard description at the top: "Create a Java project in the workspace or in an external location."
2. if the location does not exist but can be created: "The wizard will create the project at the existing location."
3. if the location exists write: "The wizard will try to configure the JRE and the project layout based on files found at the specified existing location. Otherwise default settings will be used."
Besides that there are lots of other strange bugs/messages when creating a project from source where the directory cannot be created. Under Linux for example an confusing dialog is shown and a log entry is written.

(In reply to comment #5) > Tested in I20070503-1400: the shown string is still wrong (the suggestion from > comment 1 would be closer to what I expect): it now shows: "The wizard will > automatically configure the JRE and the project layout based on the specified > existing source." > > BUT: there is really no source in there: it is completely empty and hence > "specified existing source" is just wrong.
Good point... "The wizard will try to configure the JRE and the project layout based on files found at the specified existing location."
> I recommend to: > 1. rename the radio item to "existing location" which reflects the facts > and would be better alligned to the wizard description at the top: > "Create a Java project in the workspace or in an external location."
I think we had the exact same discussion last year, and any year before. "existing location" is wrong too because you can also specify a non existing location... IMHO correct would be: (.) Create new project in Workspace ( ) Create project in external location
But Erich wanted to have the focus on the fact that it is possible to create a new project _from existing source_, hence the wording.

> because you can also specify a non existing location... Sorry I meant "external location".
>But Erich wanted to have the focus on the fact that it is possible to create a >new project _from existing source_, hence the wording. I know that story.
So, you might add a third radio: o create in workspace o create at external location o create from existing source
This would have the advantage that the option section doesn't change enablement while typing into the location field.
Created an attachment (id=65908) Checks whether external project can be created

(In reply to comment #8) > Created an attachment (id=65908) [details] > Checks whether external project can be created >
ähh, wrong bug? See Bug 185527
Didn't know about your bug and was just dropping my stuff here.

attachment.desc: Checks whether external project can be created

bug.short_desc: Project does not build

long_desc.thetext: We have removed the third-party code that was unused, but the entries still exist in the classpath and manifest files. These need to be removed also. Changes are required in org.eclipse.mtj.core and org.eclipse.mtj.extension.preverify. org.eclipse.mtj.extension.dplp.nokia.pcsuite has problems also, but removing the references will not enable to code to build while we wait for the license resolution. In mtj.core you also need to exclude the internal.ota code from building. <classpathentry excluding="org/eclipse/mtj/core/internal/ota/" kind="src" path="src"/>

Created an attachment (id=49182) Changes made to manifest and .classpath
Here are the changes I made to build. I wanted to make sure everything was in a stable state before changing code in the new tree.

Please add org.mortbay.http.jar org.eclipse.mtj.core\lib folder. (F5 refresh) And also Cona.jar and ConnJNI.dll to org.eclipse.mtj.extension.dplp.nokia.pcsuite folder. (F5)
After that the MTJ project builds nicely.
Please do not add these binaries to CVS.

Arto, I don't understand your comment. Are you suggesting that I use the local copy that I have of these binaries to create the build, instead of removing them from the code? I have also noticed that asm-all-2.2.1.jar is back in CVS in the preverify plug-in. Is this desired? Have we received clearance?
I support Kevin's proposal. We need to be able to generate builds that can be downloaded by users.

At the meantime it is easiest to use local copies of those binary files, if we cannot put those n Eclipse cvs. I did add those to cvsignore file.
During build we can temporarily copy those to enable the build.
I assume that there will be approval soon, so this way there is minimum changes.
Certainly if there is nogo from Janet, we have to remove the dependencies and cut those binaries out, but I would not do tha now.
Opinions? -Arto

I would really like to see our Milestone build this week, and don't think that it should be done using code that is not in CVS, that we would need to manualy delete to make the build. I don't think we will hear back from Janet by tomorrow. We can put a label on the affected plug-ins so that it is easy to go back to the changed files if we receive legal approval, if you think that would help.

Now project compiles, the newly Eclipse legal accepted third party binaries are now in n(asm and jetty). Only exception is in the PC Suite wrapper, which has not yet taken through the Janets process. So, the org.mortbay.http.jar is now in the cvs and also the asm-all-2.2.1.jar & emptyapi.zip are there. When taking the MTJ binary build, the developer has to download also the CONN.zip from Forum Nokia and unzip the package on top of the MTJ plugins.
complete.

bug.short_desc: The partMenu tag should include an optional default action id attribute

long_desc.thetext:
The default action id attribute would specify a default action to be associated with the toolbar button before the user selects one from the drop down list.
For example:
<partMenu menubarPath="/diagramMenu/formatGroup" toolbarPath="/toolbarViewGroup" defaultAction="toolbarSelectAllAction" id="selectMenu"> </partMenu>

To implement this change, consider creating a subclass to the ActionMenuManager that stores the default action and abstracts the changes made to fix the SelectMenuManager and ArrangeMenuManager in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=155549

bug.short_desc: ClassCastException in TextDirectEditManager when cell editor control is not Text

long_desc.thetext:
Using R1_0_maintenance branch.
A recent change in the TextDirectEditManager assumes that the cellEditor control is always a Text object.
I am getting ClassCastExceptions when a ComboBoxCellEditor is being used where the control object is a CCombo.
Created an attachment (id=49194) proposed patch
Committed the patch and overrode the method setLocator() to locally cache the locator as well.

bug.short_desc: [Regression] Can't preview joint dataset which is extended from library in HTML/PDF

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Can't preview joint dataset which extended from library in HTML/PDF

bug.short_desc: Debug View not closed in Java Perspective if it never has focus

long_desc.thetext:
3.2.1
1. Turn on view management to java perspective 2. Launch a java debug session 3. Debug View is opened. 4. Do not click on anything in the debug view. (e.g. debug target, thread, etc.) 5. Click on the terminate button.
The debug session is terminated, but the debug view is not closed. If I click on a target or thread from the view before the terminate, the view will be closed.
Only seems to happen when the "switch perspective" setting is on "prompt". As well, only the debug view opens in this case - the variables and breakpoints are missing.
If a step is peformed (context is activated, then this works as expected). It looks like our view manager is not getting a context activation when the prompter is on.
Not planned for 3.3

bug.short_desc: Error handling when WorkflowRunner is run from eclipse plugin

long_desc.thetext:
When workflow is used from an eclipse plugin there is no error message logged in the case when workflow file can not be opened/found.
WorkflowRunner's prepare method contains try block in which workflow initialization takes place. The block catch clause handles only ConfigurationException but WorkflowFactory throws the following exception: IllegalArgumentException("Couldn't load file " + fileName).
This issue leads to a workflow log without any error messages.
May be the better idea could be be to throw ConfigurationException(IllegalArgumentException)?
TOBEFIXEDIN411
TOBEFIXEDIN411

Caught that special IllegalArgumentException in WorkflowRunner and it will be thrown further as a ConfigurationException. Other IllegalArgumentExceptions will be rethrown.
Maybe its worth to think about catching runtime exceptions to avoid similar problems? Anyway, this special case is now handled.
- WorkflowRunner 1.36

bug.short_desc: [IDE] bad value in the IIDEActionConstants

long_desc.thetext: code sample : ----------------------------------------------------------------------- /** * Edit menu: name of group for extra Find-like actions (value "find.ext"). */ public static final String FIND_EXT = "cut.ext"; //$NON-NLS-1$ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- Seems there should be "find.ext" instead of "cut.ext". This may be the cause of the messages that can appear in the error log on a rcp product : "Reference item find.ext not found for action null"
The constant needs to be changed to "find.ext" even though clients will not see this change until they recompile.
Fixed >20060906. Thanks for reporting this!
Verified using I20061031-0656.

bug.short_desc: [hotbug_request] NullPointerException from PlatformActivator.run()

long_desc.thetext:
I am getting the following NullPointerException from PlatformActivator.run()
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(PlatformActivator.java:60) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:92) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:68) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:400) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:64) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)

Are you sure you are using Eclipse 3.1.2 ? From the trace it seems like you are using 3.2 or above.
If it is 3.2, the exception happens as org.eclipse.core.runtime plugin can't find the extension point org.eclipse.core.runtime.applications which is a bit strange as the extension point is defined in this very same plugin.
I would suggest the following: - If running Eclipse from a command line, run once with "-clean" option. If running from PDE, open your launch configuration, switch to the "Configuration" tab, and select "Clean the configuration area before launching" - Make sure you don't use Eclipse 3.1.2 for hosting while using runtime plugins from 3.2 for development (or as a target). If it is, use either 3.1.x plugins in both host and target or 3.2.x plugins in both host and target.
If this won't help, please provide details on how you launch Eclipse.

Hello,
We can't reproduce the problem anymore.
Regards, Jack
Closing as non-reproducable.

bug.short_desc: Problems when closing unsaved editor and deleted project

long_desc.thetext:
Here is the scenario: 1. User creates Java project and a java class "MyClass" within this project. 2. User 'dirties' the editor containing the java class. 3. User deletes the Java project 4. User closes workbench 5. Save Resources dialog box pops-up -> user decides not to save the file containing java class and clicks "OK" PROBLEM: 1. Even though user decided not to save the file, the following dialog box pops-up before workbench closes: "Could not save workbench layout. Reason: Problems occured saving workbench." Details: "Unable to save perspective: Workspace - Java. Unable to save editor: MyClass.java." 2. On restarting workbench the following error box pops-up: "Could not restore workbench layout. Reason: Problems occured restoring workbench." Details: "Unable to restore perspective: Workspace - Java. Unable to create editor: MyClass.java"
This problems spans accross all types of files in all perspectives. It is not specific to Java Perspective only. We do experience the same problem in Websphere Integration Developer.
Best Regards!

bug.short_desc: Option to ignore or change search order for compile-time dependencies

long_desc.thetext:
It would be a very useful feature to be able to either change the search order for compile-time dependencies, and/or ignore workspace plug-ins altogether.
Consider the following example:
An RCP exists in the workspace and a dependent plug-in also exists in the same workspace. Development is being done on both concurrently. Assuming that the plug-in is more or less "stable" and exported/deployed to the target platform the RCP uses, the RCP project should be able to specify that the compile-time dependency is the plug-in from the target environment, rather than from the workspace. Currently, changes made to the dependent plugin are immediately reflected in the RCP because the PDE looks in the workspace first. The result is that everything in the downstream development/testing environment breaks.
Windows XP Eclipse 3.2.1 (M20060802-0800) & Eclipse 3.3M1
Thanks for your consideration. =)

by definition, PDE is about development and workspace; and by definition, workspace projects must take precedence over anything in the target.
If you want some workspace plug-ins to be ignored at a particular point in time, just close the project(s).

(In reply to comment #1) > by definition, PDE is about development and workspace; and by definition, > workspace projects must take precedence over anything in the target. > > If you want some workspace plug-ins to be ignored at a particular point in > time, just close the project(s). >
Closing the project certainly gets around the problem.... Though - the (published) description of the PDE is to "facilitate the automation of plug-in build processes". The JDT, for example, allows a user to specify the local project dependencies for building (in the build-path). I'm not sure I understand where the definition of workspace wrt PDE facilitates the build process if it actually (imho) gets in the way of building multiple plug-in products with dependencies. I think I'm missing something here in the purpose of the PDE. Can you point me to more substantial information/docs on the PDE (purpose, etc?) Thanks. =)

From the top level menu, go to Help > Help Contents > Plug-in Development Environment Guide. This would be a good start.
Incidentally, where is it published that the purpose of PDE is to "facilitate the automation of plug-in build processes"?
I am starting to get the feeling that we are talking about different things here and that you should be talking to the pde/build department.

Thanks for the pointers, Wassim. Here is the one you requested - it's from the Eclipse/PDE public web site. My quote is taken from the first line of the first paragraph: "The Plug-in Development Environment (PDE) provides tools to create, develop, test, debug, build and deploy Eclipse plug-ins, fragments, features, update sites and RCP products."
http://www.eclipse.org/pde/
Hmmm - when I submitted the enhancement request, I followed the links to PDE/build - though I'm guessing once it hits bugzilla some of that information is lost. *chuckle* I thought I *was* talking to the pde/build department. Nope - a quick look at the "assigned-to" has just shown me this is ui. Yikes.
I'm reopening this & redirecting it as a build component enhancement.

Hi Susan,
It's still unclear to me what you are trying to do, so let me explain briefly how things work:
When computing the classpath of a plug-in project X, PDE/UI will put on X's classpath all of X's dependencies. If X depends on Y and Y is both in the target and in the workspace, the workspace copy masks the target copy. This is by design and this part is non-negotiable (hence the WONTFIX resolution of the defect in PDE/UI land).
If you want this classpath computation to be modified to pick up target rather than workspace, then this is NOT a scenario that we plan to support in PDE/UI, as it goes against the basic premise of self-hosting.
On the other hand, pde/build can be used to package plug-ins independent of workspace and pde/ui etc. It can build/package an arbitrary set of plug-ins if you craft the right scripts, etc. So if this is what you want, then pde/build would be a good place to have a discussion to see what is possible and what is not.

(In reply to comment #6) Hi Wassim -
From your description, the UI component is what I wanted.
So - I *think* I am beginning to better understand what the PDE is doing. I'm specifically looking for more control (read: separation, or the option of separation) of compile-time vs. runtime plug-in resolution. I'm not sure I understand why that violates the basic premise of self-hosting (Eclipse launches another instance and computes the plug-ins required, yes? Is there a constraint that prevents it from specifying *where* those plug-ins come from? Or is it just a design decision that the workspace always takes precedence, regardless?) If I can't figure out why this is after a little more research, I'll take my questions back to the mailing lists so as not to clutter your mailbox more. ;-)
However, I do understand that what I'm asking is something that the PDE project won't consider adding: your description of what I'm asking (control over the computation of the classpath) is right on target. It's a feature I love in developing java projects, and (wrongly) assumed that it carried over to the PDE. During development, I want to control what my app sees and when. (To me, that's part of "facilitating development". Yeah, I know - just call me a control freak. Hehe)
Thanks again for putting me on the path to understanding more about the PDE. Cheers! Susan

bug.short_desc: CDT needs to know the exact architecture it's running on, not what the JVM thinks it is

long_desc.thetext:
There are a number of places in the CDT where org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.getOSArch() is called to find out what the machine architecture is so that it can determine if, for example, gdb can debug a particular executable.
On most platforms so far, just calling getOSArch has worked fine because typically people run a 64-bit Eclipse + JVM when running on x86_64, and a 32-bit Eclipse when running on x86.
However, there is a different situation on PowerPC where many of the newer machines are 64-bit, but there is only one 32-bit Eclipse built for PowerPC. So when the CDT call getOSArch on PowerPC, it always returns "ppc" regardless of whether or not the machine is actually "ppc64".
At first I proposed a change to org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.getOSArch() so that it would return a more accurate OS architecture value... in the PowerPC case, "ppc64" (when appropriate of course).
However, this idea was rejected by the Eclipse core team because they want that value to reflect what the osgi layer says the machine is.
My new proposal is to introduce a new class in org.eclipse.cdt.utils called Platform. It will mimic what the org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform class does, except that it will return a more accurate value for getOSArch().
I will attach a proposed org.eclipse.cdt.utils.Platform implementation.

Created an attachment (id=49216) More accurate version of org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.getOSArch for the CDT
This is a version of Platform for the CDT that extends getOSArch to more accurately detect the Platform's architecture.
The class offers all of the methods and constants that are currently used in the CDT, but leaves the unused ones out. I would have just "extended" org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform, but the latter is marked as final.
It's not clear to me that this is the best solution, to offer a partial clone of org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform, but it makes the modifications to the CDT classes that currently use org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform simple - just a change of import.
The patch had been applied for 3.1.2.

attachment.desc: More accurate version of org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.getOSArch for the CDT

bug.short_desc: [Preferences] Unusual behavior if all preference pages extend FieldEditorPreferencePage

long_desc.thetext:
If all available preference pages extend FieldEditorPreferencePage, then when the preference dialog comes up, the first page in the list isn't selected, as it is normally. Also, selecting one of the pages the first time presents only the name specified in the preference page contribution; none of the fields is displayed. Selecting a different page does present the fields (for the selected page). At that point then selecting the original page shows everything normally.
Even though they're not visible, the fields and their associated widgets are apparently there, as some automated tests that we have written using Abbot don't seem to trip over the fact that the items aren't visible.
I can provide a document with screen shots if needed.

Recently we've also found that if three preference pages are available, the behavior described in this ticket occurs. But if a fourth preference page (that also extends FieldEditorPreferencePage) is added, the behavior becomes normal.
Is this still an issue in 3.3?

bug.short_desc: service impl field doesn't work after switching from BU to TD

long_desc.thetext:
The service impl field on the Service Wizard page 1 fails to recognize a valid WSDL if the scenario type is changed from bottom-up to top-down.
To reproduce: ============= 1. create a web project, import a wsdl into it 2. select the project and launch the Service generation wizard. The bottom-up scenario type is selected by default. 3. Switch to top-down scenario, then browse to the wsdl in the project. 4. Back on page 1, the "Select a service definition" message does not go away and the next and finish buttons remain disabled
The combination of changes in bug 135570 and bug 155114 may be causing this.
Smells like a regression. Would you please drive in a fix, working with Peter as appropriate? Thanks Andrew. Good catch.

Created an attachment (id=49226) do not access disposed tree.
In the validate method of WSDLSelectionWidget, there is a if block that sets the wsdl uri on the tree viewer in the widget if it's not null, and previously we always new a WSDLSelectionWidget hence the tree viewer is always null. Now that we are caching the WSDLSelectionWidget, as soon as we open the WSDL selection dialog once the tree viewer will not be null, but it is disposed when the dialog is closed. Therefore, trying to set the uri on the disposed tree causes an exception.
Since the validate method is only used by page1 of the wizard, there is no need to set the uri on the tree viewer in that method.
Ready for review/commit. Thanks!

The attached patch changes two files, WSDLSelectionWidget.java for this bug, and ServerWizardWidget.java for unrelated bug 155441.
The former is reviewed, approved and committed. Please reattach to this bug a new patch without the change to ServerWizardWidget, just in case any third parties decide to grab the patch.
For the latter, please attach just the ServerWizardWidget.java change as a patch to 155441.
Thanks - CB.

Created an attachment (id=49538) patch containing isolated fix
Removed the changes that's part of 155441.
Released to HEAD and R1_5_Maintenance under tag v200609062128.
verified in M200609141830 wtp build.

bug.short_desc: Remove columnIndices from ViewerLabelProviders

long_desc.thetext:
20060831
We need to remove the columnIndex from the ViewerLabelProvider as it no longer has any use outside of the refresh where we get the ViewerCell now anyways.
We also should add a getItem to ViewerCell for future SWT work

The API changes have been made and released. The only potentially controversial; change I can see is that DecoratingLabelProvider no longer subclasses TreeColumnLabelProvider. The Table and Tree specific providers are now much less useful as we do everything via cells - I expect we will only use them for backwards compatibility.

(In reply to comment #2) > The API changes have been made and released. The only potentially > controversial; change I can see is that DecoratingLabelProvider no longer > subclasses TreeColumnLabelProvider. The Table and Tree specific providers are > now much less useful as we do everything via cells - I expect we will only use > them for backwards compatibility. > Ok. I looked at the changes and they look fine to me but now I ask myself if we shouldn't remove those IColorProvider, ... interfaces from ViewerLabelProvider and changes all method signatures from get*(Object element) to get*(ViewerCell). Why would I do that is that I think of all those guys implementing ToolTips would have to subclass ViewerLabel for each column.
A thing I cannot understand is that updateLabel(ViewerLabel label, ViewerCell cell) directly referrs to the ILabelProvider, ... . This is simply not what I expect. In future people don't need any of those interfaces any more. They could simply subclass ViewerLabelProvider and they are ready.
Created an attachment (id=49842) proposal how to change ViewerLabel-API
> implementing ToolTips would have to subclass ViewerLabel for each column. ^^^^^^^^^^^^ ViewerLabelProvider
Verified in 20060919-0100

bug.short_desc: ActionFilterService should cut down on calls to ISelection::equals()

long_desc.thetext: Currently when the ActionFilterService tries to figure out if the current selection has changed it calls equals() on the cached selection and the current selection, which is fine, however, when the selection in large the equals() method could take long time to complete, so, the proposed patch tries to test for equality using identity comparison of the ISelections first and if they are not equal then it will resort to using equals() method. This minimizes the calls to ISelection::equals() when the cached selection and the current selection are one and the same instance of ISelection
Created an attachment (id=49204) using identity equals first before resorting to calling ISelection::equals()
The patch got committed
Committed by mmostafa, according to CVS log entry. Adding contributed keyword for IP log automation.

attachment.desc: using identity equals first before resorting to calling ISelection::equals()

bug.short_desc: Breakpoint in 'finally' not hit - test suite failing

long_desc.thetext: Note, this only seems to happen on Linux.
I was wrong, the same problem occurrs on Windows (with compiler options set to 5.0) - there are just no automated tests that show the failure for windows.

JCore, could you verify the line number attributes being set for this test case. It appears the debugger is retrieving the line number attributes as stored in the classfile, but that the debugger never hits the breakpoint with those attributes.
I'll investigate.
Indeed the line number for bytecode 44 looks suspicious. I am investigating.

Created an attachment (id=49214) Proposed fix
The fix adds a line number entry for the goto between the two finally blocks. This forces the second finally block to add its own line numebr entry again on the right line. Darin confirmed that this is fixing the issue.

Philippe,
I'll release for 3.2 maintenance and HEAD if you don't mind. Both streams have the same problem. Since Darin said this was intermittent for a long time, I believe we had a similar problem prior to the fix for the stack map table.

Fixed and released in HEAD. Released for 3.3M2.
Philippe,
+1 for 3.2.1?
I'll attach the patch for the 3.2 maintenance stream.
Created an attachment (id=49227) Proposed fix for 3.2 maintenance branch
+1 for 3.2.1. Indeed, we did not associate the #goto opcode as we should have.
pls release in 3.2.1
Released for 3.2.1. Existing tests have been updated.
Verified for 3.2.1 using build M20060908-1655
Verified for 3.3 M2 using build I20060918-0010.

bug.short_desc: GeneralPropertySection holds a reference to the model

long_desc.thetext:
This defect is the same as the RATLC00547333: Junit failure: com.ibm.xtools.modeler.ui.editors.tests -- I20060823_2130/Windows XP
The above JUnit test that fails is opening a model, do some stuff and close the model. After closing the model it checks to keep sure that there is no reference to the model. This check fails. After investigation I found that the GeneralPropertySection is holding a reference to the model in the field eObject in the super class AbstractModelerPropertySection.
I have profiled your unit test and it is not the AbstractModelerPropertySection's eObject that is holding on to the model. It is actually a class in the client code that is causing the leak.

bug.short_desc: JSP editor seems to leak memory

long_desc.thetext:
There are severe memory problems since WTP 1.5 (much rumble in the NG and a lot of bugs about it here).
I hope I found a way to reproduce it.
It is a Dynamic Web Project with just one JSP (nothing inside). Import the attached MemTest.war and do the following:
Import attached project "memtest" as WAR file. Restart eclipse. Open "Memtest.jsp". Activate "Build automatically".
Memory usage in taskmanager for javaw.exe is 92 MB
Go to this area in the JSP: <%
%> enter just one char <% r %> Remove it directly with backspace (before any error message are displayed).
Safe the file (Ctrl+S)
Wait 5-10 seconds (until memory usage in taskmanager does not change any more).
Each time you repeat it "javaw.exe" uses some KB more mem. Sometimes there are jumps of up to 3 MB. It takes really a lot saves (20-30 I would guess) to waste one MB. But if a project contains more than one small JSP the memory usage will be much bigger each save. If you wait some minutes then small amounts of the used memory are freed, but it does not decrease to the initial value.
After same minutes of sleep it was constantly at 101,700 KB. Then I made about three saves: 101,848. Then I continued filing this bug, I now I am with 101,712 => 12 KB lost. Some minutes later once run: 101,764. Some minutes later another run: reduced memory of about 500KB. 10 runs later: 102,229 KB Even with some time for GC to take place the tendency is to get worse...
Some info about my config: Eclipse 3.2 with WTP 1.5 runtime and all required plugins (VE 1.2, XSD, SDO, GEF runtimes). JDK is 1.5.0_06-b05 Settings in eclipse.ini are defaults.
Hope this helps to grab the really annoying thing. With a quite small web project (4 JSPs and an EJB project with 3 EJBs) and heavy JSP editing it took one hour to make it crash.
Created an attachment (id=49208) sample war

Thanks for the good test case ... I'll see if I can reproduce and/or if appears related so some similar "leak" bugs.
Thanks again!

bug.short_desc: Entering a long string with no spaces in the editor crashes the editor

long_desc.thetext:
Type in aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa. Copy and paste it a few times. Brings the entire system down. Also tears up system resources.
I know this is an uncommon thing to do, but thought I'd let you know since with RCP, people (us!) are building new and different non-Eclipse projects on top of these components.

http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/platform-text/development/bug-incomplete.htm
works for me using R3.2 and 3.3 M2 with Text and Java editor.

OK, my bad. I did a bad job on the explanation.
I just re-confirmed on R3.2. I also re-installed to be sure it wasn't my installation.
0. Open up an existing file with at least a few lines in it. Go to the end of the file. 1. Type in aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa. Copy it. Paste it 20-50 times. 2. Then select all the text you just pasted. This should be really big. 3. Then paste it another 20-50 times. 4. Now, the editor will still look like it works. 5. Press up and this will bring you back to the rest of your document, say a class or something 6. Now, you'll notice that all of your aaa's are gone from the bottom of your window(!!) 7. If you now try to select them (try this a few times, it's tough to grab it), this brings the app down.
Again, sorry forthe bad initial description. Thanks for looking into it.
Which editor? Java and/or Text editor?

bug.short_desc: DCR - Want to change typeahead strategy for read-only combo boxes

long_desc.thetext: in our application , selecting a choice in a combo box causes some back-end processing. So we want to be careful on the selections within a combo box. In a combo box that has many choices the user would like to type the first few chars of an item. The read-only selects based only on the first letter that was typed. This forces an implementation of a typeahead solution based on key listeners. None of this works with key listeners of course because the combo is always selecting the first letter. So if you type ahead 2 chars , if will actually fire a selection event 3 times, before arriving at the correct choice. And as you can imagine selecting three times , slows down the combo box due to the backend processing.
I changed the title to represent what I think you are saying. Please change it back if I am wrong.

Combo boxes on XP (and many other platforms) have a type ahead strategy with this behavior. Even though unwanted by your application, it is the correct operating system behavior and we shouldn't/won't change it.
If you want to override the native platform type ahead, hook a key listener and set the doit field to false. This will block the native keyboard handler from running. I don't really recomend this because you are getting in the way of native behavior. Be sure to only block characters (ie. the character field will be set in the event) or you will block arrow keys, page down etc.
We WONTFIX this.

Setting doit does stop the control from sending the key event , but it appears the native control is sending the selection event back to the combo , even though the key pressed event was never sent to the native control. The native control must hook in their own key listeners at the native level and sends the selection event , which the combo then dispatches this event back to it's selection listeners. Is this behaviour correct?

Ok, I'll try to investigate next week. Please attach a stand alone snippet that shows the doit field not working.
http://www.eclipse.org/swt/faq.php#whatisasnippet

The doit field works , as far as not sending the OS message inside the method Combo.boolean sendKeyEvent (int type, int msg, int wParam, int lParam, Event event); But it seems on the native control , it places an selection event on the event q of the display. It appears that the underlying native control registers it's own key listeners on the native control , and when you type in a char , it generates an event for the display and places it in the event q, and the combo gets it and processes it as a selection and notifies it's listeners. It's that selection , that also needs to be blocked as well.

Nevermind , i was using a key adapter and not implementing both key released and key pressed , so the event was actually getting through on one of the methods. If I block on both then events then it works fine.

bug.short_desc: C++ Build settings stored in wrong format

long_desc.thetext:
Tested on RSD Release build 20080831_0527 CDT version 3.1.1.200608070800
Import some C++ code into a C++ managed make project. This code builds perfectly OK. There are no error messages.
Save the project, Close the project then reopen the application.
Re-open RSD.
Re-open the project -> get the following message: " The project build settings are stored in a format that is no longer supported (version 2.0.0) Would you like to convert it to the newer version (3.0.0)?
If you select 'yes', you get the following error - "The managed make project file could not be written because of the following error: Could not write file: C:\path_name\.cdtbuild. "
Press OK to remove dialogs. Then everything builds fine.

This would be a build issue.
This is 100% reproducable, although I don't get the log entry. Also, the version is now 3.1.0 (was this a typo?).

(In reply to comment #3) > This is 100% reproducable, although I don't get the log entry. Also, the > version is now 3.1.0 (was this a typo?).
Yes that was a typo, sorry.

The .cdtbuild file of the sample project contains the "hidden" flag set. If you remove that flag, everything will work fine.
The root cause of the issue is that the Managed Build Info gets accessed before the project tree gets loadded into the workspace. E.g. the workspace refresh that is performed after the project import is performed after the project build request is performed (when autobuild is on). As a result the .cdtbuild file is not seen at that time. The .cdtbuild file load is performed using standard java File API, while the file store (initiated by the project update mechanism in the sample project) is performed via eclipse IResource API. The Managed Build Info serialization logic examines whether the .cdtbuild file exists in the workspace and if not, tries to create the one using the IFile.create(). The method fails in case the underlying resource exists and is "hidden".
Sometime ago I raised a bug against the platform regarding the project-scoped preferences inaccessibility from OPEN event handler on project import (see bug# 139911). The root cause of that problem was the same as the one for this bug. The bug was closed as WONTFIX.
I'm not sure whether invoking build before importing(refreshing) the complete project tree stands within eclipse build ideology. I'm going to raise a bug againts platform to get more clarification on this.
The quick solution for this bug for now could be to use java File API for storing the build info. This would make the build info load/store mechanism consistent since both would use one and the same mechanism for accessing the .cdtbuild file.
Thoughts?
Mikhail

(In reply to comment #5) BTW, I see the error message right after the project import, not after I close and re-open it.
Mikhail

-1 on using java.io. We'll need to support projects on EFS, so by passing IResource is bad.
Since there is a workaround, I'll move it off the 3.1.1 list. Thanks for looking into this Mikhail.

bug.short_desc: Quickfix "Extract to local variable" for generics replicates the error instead of fixing it

long_desc.thetext: Created an attachment (id=49209) Screenshot of the quickfix suggestion.
Moving to JDT/UI
Note, "Extract to local variable" is a quick assist, not a fix. Just tries to help you restructuring the code. The fix for the scenario is 'Add type parameters to 'ArrayList''.
setting WORKSFORME

Hi Martin,
the problem in this situation is that the "Quickfix" suggestion does not help me out of this particular situation, so it should not be displayed. As you wrote in comment #3 the correct fix for my own sample might be "Add type parameters to 'ArrayList'" (not applicable to the "javax.persistence.Query.getResultList" sample anyway).
Is this possible not to show the inappropriate quickfix ?
Thanks
Wolfgang

We have two modes: If you make a real selection (select the full word), we also show quick assist if they match the given range. If you just have a cursor, we don't show the quick assists, but just the quick fixes for the problem.
The reason is that sometimes you really want to peform a quick assist like 'Assign to local' even there is an error at that location. We need a way to allow this.
No changes planed at the moment.
Closing as it seems not possible to detect the invalid suggestion.

bug.short_desc: JSP validation does not detect double quotes in page-tag

long_desc.thetext:
This is part of a sample JSP:
<%@ page language="java" contentType="text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1" pageEncoding="ISO-8859-1""%>
Notice the double quotes at the end of the line. The first quote is coloured blue, the second black, but there is no validation error.
Tomcat is more fussy and detects it: 20:44:15,984 ERROR [[jsp]] Servlet.service() for servlet jsp threw exception org.apache.jasper.JasperException: /MyTest.jsp(2,0) Unterminated <%@ page tag at org.apache.jasper.compiler.DefaultErrorHandler.jspError(DefaultErrorHandler.java:39) at org.apache.jasper.compiler.ErrorDispatcher.dispatch(ErrorDispatcher.java:405) at org.apache.jasper.compiler.ErrorDispatcher.jspError(ErrorDispatcher.java:130) at org.apache.jasper.compiler.Parser.parseDirective(Parser.java:520) at org.apache.jasper.compiler.Parser.parseElements(Parser.java:1552) at org.apache.jasper.compiler.Parser.parse(Parser.java:126)

Created an attachment (id=49211) Full thread dump
I took a full thread dump when I came back, about 40 minutes after the errors above. It showed the Java builder's call to createMarker waiting on the workspace lock, and apparently no other threads holding it.

It looks like this session was in a bad state due to OutOfMemoryError. Once the VM is out of memory, secondary failures are likely to happen. Since one of the OOME occurred while releasing a lock, it doesn't surprise me that the process ended up hung on that lock. Not much we can do about this, unless there's a reproducible case that produces the OOME.

bug.short_desc: [About] Improve about dialog to present non resolved bundle and give cause

long_desc.thetext:
Committeers builds wtp-M-1.5.1-200608300436.zip (no errors) and wtp-M-1.5.1-200608302118.zip (one failed unit test) do not allow the creation of any WTP project types aside a static web project.
No errors in the log, the preferences dialog looks normal (all WTP related items are available).
I just tried with the wtp-sdk-M-1.5.1-200608311445 build... about to pass the smoke test....

Hi Chuck,
you used the SDK build, which makes the difference. I just checked again:
wtp-M-1.5.1-200608312130.zip (most recent build) => does not work (no errors/warnings) ! wtp-sdk-M-1.5.1-200608311445.zip => Works ! (1 unit test error)
So the non-SDK builds are broken.
Created an attachment (id=49244) "New project" wizard from non-sdk-build
CCing you David... do you have any ideas? whats missing?
Beats me ... but perhaps one of us can do a "diff", or your developers test a non-SDK build?

I'm even more confused, because wtp-sdk-M-1.5.1-200608312130.zip does not work either (yes, the SDK build !).
To avoid confusion: I always tried it with a blank eclipse installation with a new workspace. Involved files are (all official releases from the final Callisto release) : eclipse-SDK-3.2-win32.zip emf-sdo-runtime-2.2.0.zip GEF-runtime-3.2.zip VE-runtime-1.2.zip xsd-runtime-2.2.0.zip
I did probably more than 30 WTP installations over the months (including the 1.5.0 installation with the files above), so I would exclude an error of mine.

That explains it....
We require a new base for these maintensance releases...
For instance, the following drivers with this build:
# The Eclipse driver used in this build is eclipse-SDK-M20060830-0800-linux-gtk.tar.gz. You can find a suitable driver for your platform at here # The EMF driver used in this build is emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-M200608241248.zip # The GEF driver used in this build is GEF-SDK-3.2.zip # Java EMF Model Runtime driver used in this build is JEM-SDK-M20060825.zip
Please reopen if you still see a problem with these versions

OK, this did the trick. I used eclipse-SDK-M20060830-0800-win32.zip. All the other required plugins (EMF, GEF, VE) work with their initial Callisto release versions.
Isn't there a kind of "contract" that there should be no API changes beetween eclipse maintenance releases (3.2.0 to 3.2.1), so that WTP 1.5.0 should run with all 3.2.0 releases, and WTP 1.5.1 should run with all 3.2.0 releases ?

Chuck, Wolfgang make a good point that's definitely the goal and ideal.
Wolfgang, since we are not purely API clean yet, we may not always be able to achieve this.
And, ... while there might be times we could not maintain "workability" with downlevel pre-reqs, there should be enough constraints in place there'd at least be an error message in the log ... Wolfgang, did you check your log for messages ... about unsatisfied constraints?

I completely agree this should be the goal, but we did need to react to a few "internal" api references this release, and we did add this new lower bound constraint - actually I wonder if this is what happened.... the new constraint might have prevented the startup of several bundles....
We added this constraint:

(In reply to comment #18)
Well, be gentle with that computer :) I did try your test case, and immediately saw the error in the log:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 2 0 2006-09-12 01:44:50.781 !MESSAGE One or more bundles are not resolved because the following root constraints are not resolved: !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.osgi 2 0 2006-09-12 01:44:50.781 !MESSAGE Bundle update@plugins/org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ui_1.1.0.v200609102340.jar was not resolved. !SUBENTRY 2 org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ui 2 0 2006-09-12 01:44:50.781 !MESSAGE Missing required bundle org.eclipse.ui.workbench_[3.2.1,4.0.0).

(ten tests later) No more error message. You mean WORKSPACE\.metadata\.log, don't you ? I even tried it at another machine with no recent eclipse and a new workspace, and there was no message, too. Does eclipse write the "first plugin version message shown" information to any directory other than the workspace ?
By the way, I uploaded my zipped eclipse from comment #15 one more time because the zip file seems to have gone broken. Did you try it with this file or with a custom installation ?
Does the parameter "eclipse.ee.install.verify" from "config.ini" interfer with my problem ? I switched it to "true" by setting it in config.ini, but this did not bring up any validation errors either.

Debugging resolution problems is always hard. it is very strange that the messages are not being logged. At least the first time.
For future reference, running with -console and typing "ss" will show you all known bundles and their state. For any bundle that is not resovled or active, type "diag ##" where ## is the bundle's number. This will tell you why the bundle is not resolved. Follow that trial until you find the actual problem. I wrote a little utility a while ago (it may be on StateHelper or some such) that did this searching for you and basically showed just the dead-ends. Perhaps that should be itegrated into the console.
another suggestion here is to have the About -> Configuration Details show any problems wrt unresolved plugins.

Jeff, the "diag" command uses the StateHelper methods you mention.
We only log unresolved bundles in the following cases: - if you use -debug or -dev and the state timestamp has not changed (-clean forces this) - if an error occurs starting the application.
Wolfgang, run with the -debug -clean options to see if the resolution errors are logged.

(In reply to comment #23) > Output of "dialog ###": > osgi> diag 124 > update@plugins/org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ui_1.1.0.v200609102340.jar [124] > Missing required bundle org.eclipse.ui.workbench_[3.2.1,4.0.0).
Just noticed this message. From you previous posting of the "ss" command you have org.eclipse.ui.workbench_3.2.0.I20060605-1400 installed but org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ui_1.1.0.v200609102340.jar requires version 3.2.1. Is that correct? It looks like you either did not get 3.2.1 platform installed or we have a version mismatch in org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ui_1.1.0.v200609102340.jar

Created an attachment (id=50033) Logfile of "eclipse.exe -clean -debug"

Sorry to reopen the bug once again, but I feel misunderstood ;-).
The original bug report is resolved because I know that a newer Eclipse than 3.2.0 will work.
BUT I had no chance to find out why the combination of 3.2.0 and WTP 1.5.1M did not work ! No error message in the log (this was up to now the only place I knew about where problems are reported).
How does a eclipse user find out that some plugin cannot be resolved ? He/She will probably not look at the "Help" - "About Eclipse SDK" - "Configuration Details" dialog and scroll through pages of plugin information and he/she will not know that "Installed" does not mean "Resolved".
PLEASE log the information about non-resolved plugins at first eclipse startup, because this is a really critical problem (at least if you do not use an update server).

Logging each startup is not the solution here. The SDK is shipped with bundles a required execution environment of J2SE-1.5. These bundles will not be resolved on 1.4 VMs, that is fine it just means some functionality is not available. Logging these resolution messages each startup will fill the log with unwanted information.
Seems like the configuration details is the correct place to show this information.
What stands against logging the bundles on first startup and if the "-clean" option is set ? "-clean" seems to be quite well-known commandline switch (even I knew it ;-) ).
Changing summary to make more sense.
*** Bug 163190 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Summary: 1). The original problem was fixed. 2). The user would like unresolved bundle messages printed out every time Eclipse starts.
This will not happen. We already log the message the first time Eclipse starts as well as when you clean your configuration area (-config)
As Tom mentions in comment #29 some of these unresolved messages are ok.

As I wrote in comment #28, there is NO, NO, NO error message on first eclipse startup with a new workspace and a new eclipse "installation" (unzipped) !
So "We already log the message the first time Eclipse starts" in comment #30 is actually wrong. Please verify it with the old eclipe bundle I provide in comment #15.
"eclipse -config" does not show an error message either, only "eclipse -debug -clean", which is probably unknown to most users.
I think it is not a good solution that even on first eclipse startup there is no log output about unfulfilled constraints !
When you close the bug the next time I will give up about it ;-)

Changing summary to reflect user's real issue. Old Summary: No easy-to-spot warning if minimal bundle constraints not met
Talked to Tom about this and there is code in EclipseStarter#startup which does the check. We should reconsider the "only log if in debug or dev mode" option.
See also bug 127084 and its duplicates.
*** Bug 174515 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

There are many legitimate cases where one has bundles installed that do not resolve. In previous times we got beat up by people saying that they didn't want to see all these messages in the log if things were really ok. We have no real way of telling the difference so we turned the messages off unless we could tell that you wanted this kind of info. for exampel if you were running in -debug mode. We feel damned if we do and damned if we don't...

(In reply to comment #37) > There are many legitimate cases where one has bundles installed that do not > resolve. In previous times we got beat up by people saying that they didn't > want to see all these messages in the log if things were really ok. We have no > real way of telling the difference so we turned the messages off unless we > could tell that you wanted this kind of info. for exampel if you were running > in -debug mode. We feel damned if we do and damned if we don't...
That is an understandable dilemma. Seems to me like it could be resolved by defining multiple levels of "required" for bundles. In other words, have a "critical" requirement and an "optional" requirement. Log the criticals all the time (actually, I'd say notify the user visibly about them, see Bug 174515) and only the "optionals" during -debug. IS that feasible to implement?

the challenge is that there are whole subgraphs of the dependency graph that may be orphaned and that may or may not be ok. We already have optional and strong (i.e. normal) dependencies. But in a loosely coupled system you may have chunks that are not related by any explicit dependency. One easy example is SWT. It has a set of fragments specific to various platforms. on linux it is reasonable for people to have both GTK and Motif installed since it is in the end a user choice for how to run. In either case one of them is going to be unresolved but that is ok.

Suggestion: -Log optional bundles only if "-clean -debug" is set. -Log required bundles on first startup and on "-clean".
Probably the GTK/Motif bundle would need a constraint which says "need one of GTK or Motif", if none is present this would be an error and logged on first startup. If only one is present this would be just a informational message logged with "-clean -debug". Same for the Java dependencies: Java 1.5 is an optional constraint => log unresolved only with "-debug" But any plugin which cannot be resolved and which does not define an "optional" constraint should be logged as "error" on first startup or "-clean".
Does this suggestion make sense to you ?

We are not going to make everyone happy here. Jeff sparked my memory in comment 37. There are many cases where it is expected that bundles will not be resolved. The challenge is the framework does not (and cannot) know what is really "optional" for a running product.
One simple example is the apt support in jdt when running on JavaSE-1.6. They have three bundles that have a required EE of JavaSE-1.6. When running on JavaSE-1.5 or less these 3 bundles will be unresolved. For the SDK product this is fine, every thing functions fine but some of the extra functionality for apt is not available. If we start logging errors in this case then it will become a problem.
The challege is at the framework level we have no idea if these 3 bundles are critical to the functionality of the product. The only time we have any clue is if the application failed to launch. In this case we *do* log unresolved errors without the -debug option because that may have something to do with why the application failed to launch.
IMO logging unresolved errors will lead to more invalid bug reports opened against us because we have no idea wheather the unresolved bundle is expected or not.

We cannot automatically log resolution errors to the log because there are too many cases where unresolved bundles are valid and should not cause an error log. Doing so would make many people unhappy.
The Equinox team discussed this at length and did not see anything we could do at the log level. We think it could be useful if resolution information was somehow displayed on the plugin details page in the about dialog.
Wolfgang would you be able to provide a patch for the UI part (AboutPluginsDialog in org.eclipse.ui.workbench)? We could help you with the core part to get the diagnostic.
Me ? Sorry, I'm not a eclipse developer, just a user complaining about everything ;-)
*** Bug 177342 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to comment #43) > Wolfgang would you be able to provide a patch for the UI part > (AboutPluginsDialog in org.eclipse.ui.workbench)? We could help you with the > core part to get the diagnostic. >
I would be willing to help on this one. If I understand correctly , this is only about displaying the current bundle status in the plugin details dialog ?

Yes. I'm not a UI guy so take my suggestions with a grain of salt.
Maybe a new resolution column could be added to show resolution status, similar to the signed column. Then a new button could be added to show resolution info. Or maybe the existing "Show Signing Info" button could be generalized to show both the signing info and resolution info. When a bundle is unresolved you would show the details of the resolver errors that caused it to be unresolved.

Created an attachment (id=63040) patch to display state of installed bundles
This is my take at adding a column to the "plugins details..." dialog in order to display the current state of each plugin. also added a button to display non ready plugins as this bug is all about diagnostic. This new button will allow the display of non ready plugins (eg: installed)

Now, I would also like to display why a bundle is not in a ready state (a la -console diag) but to be able to report that, it looks like I need to duplicate some code from org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseCommandProvider, since everything is in an internal package.
which doesn't seem like a particularly good idea.
Is there a way to programmatically call the osgi console, launch a diag XXX and get the result back ?
Or may be an OSGI service that would provide this kind of information (a la org.eclipse.osgi.service.resolver.PlatformAdmin) ?

Patrick: Thanks for the patch! It looks good but I do have one concern. Elsewhere in the UI (when filtering by activities or in the keys preference page, for instance) when we filter by some criteria we typically add a checkbox that (if enabled) adds the missing content back into the UI rather than a button that toggles two sets of input. If you have time could you update the patch to have that behavior? If you dont have the time I understand - I'll try and get to it early next week myself. Thanks again!
Patrick thank you for your help. There is no way to programmatically invoke the command of the console. The logic would have to be duplicated.

Created an attachment (id=63161) patch to display state of plugins + diagnostic
take 2. implemented the checkBox to add the installed plugin (instead of toggling content) as suggested by Kim.
As I was at it, I also implemented an almost complete filter on the list of plugin, by provider, name, version and/or id. Quite useful when you have 100+ plugins.
I can probably refine the filter with - signed status (but the order by does a fine job at it, since it's a on/off state) - individual status (but do we really care ?)
for me the main use case of this screen is when something doesn't work properly, with the provided filter it's very easy to isolate what you are looking for.
I also duplicated the logic of the diag command to get a diagnostic as indicated by Pascal. this is displayed in a tray, a la signing info.

bug.short_desc: Jars Added to WEB-INF/lib not picked up in Java Build Path

long_desc.thetext:
When jars are added to the WEB-INF/lib folder they do not seem to get added to the java build path. This causes compile errors for java files that reference these jars. The problem can be resolved by going to project properties and adding the jars manually.
1. Install a server like Tomcat 5. 2. Create a Dynamic Web Project. Create a simple java class to create a Web Service From. 3. Create a Bottom Up Web Service from teh java file. Move the Test slider all the way up to test Client. 4. The Client project generated has errors. It is not able to resolve classes in the jars added to the WEB-INF/lib folder.
To get around this problem I have to add the jars manually in the project properties. I do not have to do this in WTP 1.5.
I can also reproduce the problem by creating a dynamic web project with some java file that references a jar in the WEB-INF/lib. I then paste the jar in the lib folder and it is not picked up and there are compile errors.

I don't know if it is a difference in the build, our test systems, or luck, but I have tried this a few times with wtp-sdk-S-2.0M1-200608311705.zip on WinXP/JDK1.5.0_07 and have not duplicated this behavior. Everything seemed to work okay. The jars appeared in the "Web App Libraries" container like they should.

Hi Mark,
I just smoked the 2.0 build - This worked for me fine...
I just tried the very latest build.... S-2.0M1-200609010131/
Larry, Chuck, thanks for trying. I couldn't reproduce this either on wtp-sdk-S-2.0M1-200609010131. Verified.
Closed.
